reviewText: What a find with four great old movies on one DVD for only $ 3.99.  EdwardArnold was terrific as a blind detective in Eyes in the Night.  William Powellwas fantastic as Philo Vance in The Kennel Murder Case.  Lloyd Bridgesgave a fine performance in The Limping Man.  James Mason shows why heis one of the all-time great movie actors with his performance in The Spy inWhite.  Don't miss out and purchase this DVD for your collection before theyrun out of copies.

reviewText: The most entertaining of these group of four old movies was Edward Arnold as a blind detective in "Eyes in the  Night."  His seeing eye dog and human assistant were great in helping the brilliant detective solve the crime.  Second best was "The Kennel Murder Case", which had little to do with dogs but was an interesting murder in a locked room problem.  This gave William Powell the chance to show what he could do as the detective he would play in the successful Thin Man series later on.  "The Spy in White" was a quaint old show with an especially repulsive bad guy derived from the book "The Eunuch of Stamboul."  I believe "Stamboul" is an old variation of the name for Turkey's capital city Istanbul where most of the action occurs.  It has all the elements of oriental deception, murder, and sinister characters.  This one shows its age more than the others.  "The Limping Man" is a British movie starring Lloyd Bridges in London.  It is the least successful movie but not a bad mystery save for the disappointing ending.

reviewText: I particularly enjoyed seeing the early James Mason film "Secret of Stamboul", which is titled The Spy in White on this disc.Why it's Good - excellent value (and enticingly, this says "number 5 in the series" on it) 4 good movies for less than what you'd pay to see at bad one at the contemporary theater. Slinky plots with old-timey settings and dialogue.Why Some Will Quibble - Although the print quality is actually very good (and the sound is even better) if one factors how problematic it is to find complete prints of less-well-known films and undamaged sound of ANY film that isn't created digitized... some viewers may become impatient with passages containing no sound, or several feet of film being missing from a scene such that one character starts to ask a question and it jumps to the end of the person's answer.But you don't lose critical dialogue and as big of a snob as I am about sound, the clarity of the sound (1936 film here!) is to be praised.Annoyances - the disc company's logo pops up for several minutes at intervals - in the lower, right.But hey - you could shell out 20 bucks for a copy that comes with no other films and pray that it's 10% better than this!
summary: Rare Titles - Good Time for All

reviewText: First, for the low price you just can not go wrong.  I am a big fan of William Powell and these four movies are not easy to find.In my humble opinion only the Kennel murder case and Eyes in the Night are of good sound and picture quality.Of course it is becoming harder and harder to define good picture quality.  When you take movies as old as these and plant them on a 55 inch plasma tv you are just going to see a lot of quality problems.It is too bad that some of these classics were not transferred over to digital before they deteriorated.If anyone comes across a better quality print of these PLEASE let me know!
summary: Two hits and two misses.  Still worthwhile.

reviewerName: Scotman's Film & Book Reviews "Film & Book Re...
reviewText: I recently discovered these series of Mystery Films made by Echo Bridge Entertainment.  I'm not sure how many volumes of DVDs they've created, but they really whet the appetite for these types of classic film noir gems.I watched Volume 5 since it has my favorite actor William Powell, but I'm getting ahead of myself.  I thought the best way to review this DVD is to give a mini review of each film.  Also, the set sadly does not have any kind of features, no trailers, and not even any chapters where you can pick up where you left off! A star is subtracted due to this odd development!"Eyes In The Night" was a very interesting film.  A blind detective and his dog Friday solve a murder which leads to a den of Nazi spies out to get plans to a new American weapon.  Though the film does not reveal much about the secret weapon, and there is a bit of overacting, it's fun to watch.  Edward Arnold is the detective and he uses his senses of smell and touch and his own blindness to put one over on the spies.  Donna Reed plays the snarky daughter in law who falls for the guy who is murdered early in the film.  Keeps my interest throughout -- 5 out of 5!  This film had a sequel a few years later, "Hidden Eyes" which I need to find."The Kennel Murder Case" with William Powell continues the Philo Vance films that were popular at the time, based on the books of the same name.  Philo and others enter a dog show and though he loses the show, he gets a fascinating locked-room murder that everyone thinks is a suicide but in fact is a murder!  The murder of Archer Coe is difficult to solve since he had several enemies who all would love to see him dead.  Dapper Powell and his well-dressed manner and always witty repartee is really fun to watch.  5 out of 5 stars!  Of course this film has been sequeled as well, including Basil Rathbone as Philo Vance in one of the series."The Spy In White" was interesting, but the quality of the film was fairly bad in several spots to where you miss some of the words and action.  A complex ring of "revolutionaries" that want to overthrow the Turkish government are gun-running and using a tobacco company as a front, which is little suspected by their new manager, Captain Larry, played by a very young James Mason, does a little spy work and falls in love with a girl or two in the process.  Slow in parts, but not bad.  4 out of 5 stars."The Limping Man" with a very young Lloyd Bridges starts out as an American coming to Britain on a nice propeller plane.  In an hour he will touch down in London, see a woman he has not seen in six years and hopes to rekindle an old romance with her, little knowing that the girl is being blackmailed.  Several other characters are out to get Lloyd's character and seem pretty bent on stopping him.  The police have a few good scenes too, especially the detectives who quickly (perhaps too quickly and conveniently) put the clues together.  Several things I do not like about this film -- the musical numbers that add nothing to the plot and a long drawn-out dubbed song that is simply awful.And the end is such a cheat!  It's like a plot where a guy goes along, the viewer invests all this time into the film and then "I got hit by a truck" the end (as example).  Hated that, despite a few well-done scenes.  2 out of 5 stars.I do recommend Mystery Classics as a great way to be introduced to the world of Mystery fiction as presented during the glory days of Tinseltown!
summary: Good Collection But "Limping Man" is a Cheat!

reviewText: First of all the price is right. You get 4 movies for the price of 1..!1. Kennel Murder Case....this is a Philo Vance Mystery starring William Powell. The plot is about a man who is killed in a locked room. Police rule suicide but with Philo Vance on the case the real truth comes out. This one is a 5 star mystery. Good print and sound.2. Eyes In The Night....Edward Arnold plays a blind detective involved in murder with a "sidekick" to do the dirty work and a dog as a companion. This one also a 5 star mystery. Good print and sound.3. The Limping Man....this one is about murder and smuggling in London. This one is a 3 star movie. I liked it but it is not an award winner. A British film so that will tell you something of the "style". Good print and sound.4. The Spy In White.....stars James Mason as a British officer who gets into a fight over a girl in the officer's club. Unfortunately, the other man is a Turkish Prince. Mason is forced to resign and is offered a job as a tobacco executive in Turkey. This is where the movie goes downhill. I thought the story/plot was BAD..!!.......so-so print quality and sound...this one at best a 2 star movie....my rating is 1 star..!If nothing else...buy this set for the first two movies and you'll have a real bargain.

reviewText: My favorite film in this collection is "The Kennel Murder Case" (1933) starring William Powell.  The Kennel Murder Case is William Powell at his best as the charming society sleuth Philo Vance.The four Vance films were said to be the impetus for MGM to steal Powell away to star in its enormously fabulous copy cat version "The Thin Man" series.So, if you love the Thin Man series, which is often described as the gold standard for the who done it genre, you'll love these films.These wonderful B & W film noirs are classic detective mystery films.  This collection of films were originally produced in the 1930s, 40s, and 50s.The films have been nicely transferred to DVD format.  The stars include William Powell, Lloyd Bridges, Mary Astor, Edward Arnold, Eugene Pallette, Donna Reed, Francis L. Sullivan, Hugh Wakefield, Patricia Hilliard, James Mason, Kay Walsh, and Peter Lorre, just to name a few.This is volume 5 (2005) of the Mystery Classics series.  It contains such classic mysteries as "Eyes in the Night", "The Kennel Murder Case", "The Limping Man", and "The Spy in White".The films are typically 73-85 minutes in length on average.  The directors include Robert N. Lee, Walter Summers, Andrew Martan, and Fred Zinneman.The mysteries have great plots, twists, surprise endings, and spoilers.  These suspense films are filled with magnificient psychological force--classic for their time.Lloyd Bridges becomes a unwilling sleuth to prove his innocence in the "limping man."  James Mason is thrilling as the Alfred Hitchcock undercover secret agent.These are who done its that you will want to watch again and again.
summary: Detective Mystery Films Starring William Powell
